												This is one of the hardest reviews that I’ve had to write to this date. And it’s hard because I’m giving this game a negative review, even though I love the game and they’ve pretty much been serving long time vets a sh*t sandwich for years now. A bit of background info I started playing this game back in 2009. I’ve been a premium player ever since I began playing. It's safe to say I like the game. Combat System The combat system is challenging, fun, and one of the best combat implementations I’ve ever seen in an MMORPG. It requires you to pay attention and be on the ball with things, both for melee and for mage.Stereotype archtype classes do not exist here. Healers are expected and are capable of healing and dpsing at the same time, and tanks are capable of dpsing while being meatshields in raids. You can take on many roles for groups if you know how to play your class well enough. Graphics Beautiful, realistic graphics, that in 2008, outclassed practically every other game out there, and still manage to stand well against newer mmorpgs today.  Roleplay Ok, I’m going to be bluntly honest here. The Roleplaying community in this game is absolutely toxic. Toxic. Yes, I had to reiterate it. And it’s toxic because it’s the same twenty or so people playing childish, dramatic games with one another, metagaming, and making bland RP guilds that end up imploding because they squabble with one another every three or four months like clockwork.  PvPPicture it: Sicily, 1998Twelve men are having a contest to see who can pee the furthest. One side has taken Viagra and the other side hasn’t. The side that hasn’t taken the Viagra urinates all over everyone. The side that has taken the Viagra begin to complain because they cannot pee at all. They begin smacking eachother with their peens in frustration.Now envision them hopping around wildly and telling one another they coited eachothers moms.Now envision the “I boinked yer mum” banter being in your global all day and night. This is PvP on Age of Conan. Lackluster Free to Play systemAge of Conan has an okay but restrictive Free to Play system. You are limited to one toon per account (unless you were a member, buy toon slots, or had a free account before the f2p revamp) of which you can choose any class. You get access to whatever you buy, ie, if you buy Khitai you can access t4 raids. Gold cap is 10g which sucks given the player driven economy of goods has items that cost well over 500 gold. Poor Management of game You know, how on most MMORPGS, they do little events and special deals to celebrate the game’s birthday? They actually used to do that for this game. And it was fun. They used to do little seasonal events, like other games too. And then, it’s almost like they stopped caring. Almost? They did stop caring. They implemented worldbosses, which was a step in the direction of negating any purpose of going to t1-3 raids, they no longer had to do a winter event, because they could use the excuse that the worldbosses for December and January went back to back. Then, for the last two years… slap in the faces to the community. 7th anniversary, they release a new content pack, (which you think would be a good thing) and then made us buy it. Our 8th anniversary was last month, and we got a free pet… that was a recolor of a pet that already existed in the game… and then… they turned on double AA points after there was a backlash from the community. No subscription deals, nothing.Now, you think they would learn after years of poor management and poor decisions… but this is Funcom, and they do and say things that surprise you and make you lower your expectations of them… and then make you keep lowering those expectations. Item Store Revamp and Membership changes Fast forward a couple weeks past the 8th anniversary of the game, and you’ll see they let us know they were going to revamp the item store because of its clunkiness (there was no clunkiness, you just had to actually pay attention) and wanted to make it “easier for people to get back into the game”Whats in the item store now? Well it’s certainly not their best selling items like social gear! Nooo… Now you can buy yourself an 80 in full t3 raid gear! Now you can pay money to gear yourself up in t4 and t5 raid gear without ever having to to go into those nasty raid instances again where you might have to do actual work for gear! Now you can buy 4 hour magic damage increase potions that are 400% more expensive then what they were before! Now your item store will open automatically trying to get you to buy things as you level up! Now you can call it “Age of Cashgrab!”And on top of that, they’re changing membership. So now vets are losing perks that they have earned, such as offline levels and vet tokens will be discontinued. All premium perks will be better suited towards new subscribers and fresh 80s. And they do this, because they love us long time vets…  Because they love us… and need our money... to fund TSW's and Conan Exiles's newest content.  Update 5.0: The update that shook the world  On 30th June, 2016 Funcom patched the game to its newest update and it packed in new things that I figured I'd give an update on. For starters, there's lag! No surprise there. Among the new things is that people who are f2p can now enter Khitai if they purchase (or purchased) the expansion. You can now do t2 and t3 raids! If you ever bought anything from AoC, such as points, an expansion, or membership directly from Funcom you get Dragonspine for free. This looks good on paper until you realize the fact that the f2p goldcap has not been increased, making it impossible for f2p players to buy upgraded gear.The item store also broke for a while, with the new loyalty claims and item store not delivering items to people. It took me over 24 hours and FOUR petitions to get some of the stuff I bought with my bonus points that Funcom allotted me due to my subscription.The Raid Finder system is.... interesting. One dungeon a week. Where people can join and afk the entire thing! Just like the world boss and minigames! And these people who afk cannot be kicked by the raid leader. Loot system is also different, giving t4 relics and tears along with t3 drops.  With a bit more fine tuning this could be a decent system that gives people a chance to see a raid area they might not otherwise get to go to.Loyalty Rewards for being subbed are a mixed bag for me. Offering things like vanity gear, feat specialization chart, and mounts.. with a spider mount being part of the higher tier rewards if you sub for a year. The spider mount looks aesthetically pleasing to me, but doesnt really fit in with the lore of the game.5.0 gave us a daily login reward system that screams "MOBILE GAME!" but works okay in the game. They however, made it so that you cannot claim the reward on all your toons. My initial thoughts are that the rewards are good for fresh 80s needing AA xp as that seems to be what is rewarded to you most of the time, however you can get about 4 gilding tokens a month, which is the equivalent of sending about $10 usd a month. The thing that upsets me about this though, is that it, along with the item store, are shoved down your throat with each login.  tl;dr It’s a fun game, somewhat limiting as a free player, but unfortunately has bad pvp (and bad pvp community), poor management from the company that owns it, has sold out and implemented the buy to win strategy, and should be renamed to “Age of Cashgrab” Play it if you want, but do not support this game financially. Do not encourage them.EXTRA NOTE: The most recent Q4 investor statement states that this game is now on what we refer to as "maintenance mode."

												Summer 2008. One of the hottest summers I can remember in Norway. Why? A game graphically way ahead of its time was boiling my graphics card through the side of my case on medium settings. Normally I would have just turned the settings all the way down, but the transcendent experience of these newfangled rendering techniques had me hypnotized to the point I'd rather invest in overkill airconditioning and suffer. I am sure I lost dangerous amount of weight that summer, and workmates were probably worried I was doing drugs, on account of the black lines under my eyes and the loss of weight.But it was worth it. Despite the lack of content at launch, there was no way I could hate anything about this game. Worldbuilding, music, immersion, animation and what content was actually present; all blew away any MMORPG that came before it.While it only took a year for Age of Conan to become the game it was supposed to be at launch, it was too late as 70% of the million plus playerbase had left, and the game became synonymous with 'failure' to the most attention deficit amongst MMO game consumers.The PvP was never developed to the standard I had hoped, but the PvE is still among the best there is.This is one of the greatest MMORPGs that are still alive today. If you haven't tried it yet, give it a go. If you've heard even a hum of one of the many grumpy, outdated complaints about this game, it will surprise the eyelashes right off your face.

												I've only just installed it on steam, but I played since release back in I guess 2008ish, and levelled about a dozen characters up to level 80.  The game got harsh reviews on release due to lack of endgame content, which was something the game suffered from for about the first two years.  Fortunately, they've listened to the players and now there is a mass of content.  There's no level up grind because there are more than enough quests to see you through, you could start as one of the four races and follow a completely different quest line from levels 20-45ish.  Graphics are beautiful even after a bunch of years, and the combat system is good, balanced, and easy to get used to.  The f2p version lets you into a lot of the game, you can play it through without paying and still have more content than players had on the original release, but if you want to raid regularly you'll probably want to sub to the game.  I've also noticed that a lot of groups looking for players will insist on anyone joining be a subbed player with epic gear and a particular AA build (not the games fault, players can be jerks).  That coupled with the relatively low player population can make it a bit of a solo game once you get to 80 unless you're willing to put your hand in your pocket.  That said, you can solo most of the content.The music in most areas of the game is great-the original game came with a soundtrack CD, even if you treat this as a single player game there's enough content to keep you happy for a lot more time than it'd take you to play through skyrim.  In todays world of dumbed-down games (particularly MMO's) AoC is a breath of fresh air that after some 7 years still has me coming back to it every now and then.

												I will give an honest review of the current state of the game from my point of view. Have been playing on and off since the day it launched in 2008.FIRST OFF IF YOU ARE CONSIDERING THIS GAME FOR YOUR KID IT HAS HALF FRONTAL NUDITY (BREASTS). ITS MA RATED! I play on Fury PvP under the name Laethiel I have made updates and changes to my old review, see below.PVE sideYou can level to 80 but along the way you will have a very hard time finding groups for any low level dungeons on the pvp server Fury, You will have better luck on the the crom pve server. Unles you play on EU prime time. They have a bit higher population on Crom. I had to power level my buddy to 80 on Fury due to all the missed content because of lack of groups. At end game (Level 80) you can do 6 man dungeons which aren't bad and are quite rewarding. and you will be able to do 24 man raids.. If you can find a raid.. on Fury PvP raids are rare or non existent , on crom they are somewhat more frequent since pve is all they do. They have since added a Raid finder which i hear mixed reviews about. Sign up and join a pub queue for raiding. The 24 man raid. These generally consist of 4 groups of 6 combined to form a 24 man "raid". Most bosses are tank and spank time sinks with need/greed loot rolls that are open to all regardless of class. This leads to ninja looting on occasion. Most raids will be very controlling in dispersal of loot. There are on average 2-3 pieces of epic gear that drop per raid boss and raid instances can vary in how many bosses. from 1 to 8. Raids can take a few hours to complete so set aside some spare time on raid night, especially progression raids. expect alot of elitist attitude and assholism. and don't be surprised if you come away completely empty handed.. alot... I raided for 6 months once to get a piece of tier 2 gear. PvE Can be very Grindy. The 6 man dungeon, There are many variations of these. from revamped low level dungeons called "unchained mode" to the khitai expansion pack dungeons. They are mostly quick and like i said very rewarding. I would recommend these starting out for quick epic gear. Problem is you have to be subscribed to play most content in the game so dont go in expecting a free ride, this game is hardly "free to play". You will find yourself having a difficult time getting to max level as a free to play member. Free to play model: Improving slowly. you are limited to 10 gold currency,  You can do all pve and pvp content provided you own the content. Festival,minigames and world pvp. Baby stepsGlobal chat - A fun time if you have a thick skin.. Think barrens chat in WoW. This can be worse. But they do ban people for blatant non political correctness like using the N word or spewing homophobic slurs etc. I rather enjoy it. This alone kept me coming back for years.The PvP sideThe PvP Festival The pvp festival, which pvp players enjoy more than our pve ?????tain counterparts, consists of daily pvp zones that switch around at approx. 8pm est every day to a new zone. In these zones all pvp is encouraged and guards will not intervene! this is great if you're like me, bad if you're not... plus you get pvp daily quests you can do to get pvp xp which is ok.The monthly event.This feature takes place on the 3rd week of every month starting on Tuesdays and lasting for 7 days. It takes place in one randomly picked zone (it cycles through 5 zones) and you and your friends must fight for objectives such as control domination, kill count, and the like. the rewards are pretty good. This event draws crowds of old and new players alike so get into a group/guild for it. They have group dm, solo dm, group domination. and chosen of ghullah in which you become an epic boss and try to score as many kills as you can before you die . They are at random locations in the zone and happen every 20 mins or so. There is no real notification system,youll just have to keep your eyes open. As for the rest of PvP, You have open world pvp which comes with ganking (Fury) and all that fun and now mostly happens in the daily pvp zone due to there being no guards. You have minigames you can queue up for which consist of 3 x 6v6 ctf maps, 1 x 6v6 dm map where you can smash the enemy spawn and end the match quickly and 1 x 12v12 domination map which half your team goes afk most of the time because win or lose you still get a token which you need to buy pvp gear. But you get more if you win. Problem is there jut aren't enough people left playing to even get minigames or world pvp.PvP Balance - It's like paper rock scissors. The minigame queue which i will describe below is horrible. The "balance algorithm" they supposedly installed in 2010 or so cannot seem to balance teams. So you'll end up on a good team or a lousy team. One team will have all the high ranking pvp players and healers while your team will be all low ranking players and no heals, aka cattle. This is an ongoing problem. Deal with it. Update: Lately teams haven't been too bad.Minigames - The thing is in age of conan you CAN'T join pvp minigames with a group or a friend/friends. Unless you are doing a full 6v6 tournament like a premade match and you have 2 full groups ready to go.. The public queue is completely random. You CANNOT decide who is on your team. This will induce episodes of rage. Granted there is a 50% chance you'll get your friend on your team.. They will never change this aspect. We have tried and failed to convince them for years that making it a random queue is a bad idea. They are afraid of premade stomping pugs which to be honest i would rather deal with.PvP Gear dependance is fairly high in pvp but having high gear wont make you good. AAs (Alternate Advancement Feats - do your own research) also play a role. They have lowered the requirements to obtain pvp gear significantly so it's easier than ever to get in the game. By pvp 3-4 you are already a pvp contender and it took me and my buddy less than a week and a half of steady pvp. Sieges (48v48)noone sieges. Forget about this aspect. If you try to siege a battlekeep youll have a carebear consortium allying to defend it from you. Not to mention it costs a fortune in game currency to launch an attack.The expansion pack "Rise of the Godslayer" no longer requires a sub to use so this is good. You no longer need this to get access to the AA feats tree, also good. Guilds -- It takes a long time to get off the ground and this game rewards large guilds not small ones. You can make a small guild but you'll never get anywhere without a guild city and those take time and or money and lots of manpower. To put it bluntly a guild consisting of say 200+ active unique members farming resource nodes daily would take 6 months to a year to build a guild city to full tier 3. . Some people sell these guild cities that are abandonded... I recommend buying one in this case. Again this game rewards zerg numbers. small guilds get crapped on usually. There is no alliance system and no faction system. You cannot kill guildies but you can kill anyone else. I have updated my old review to reflect the current changes and I think the changes are good. I have since been logging on more frequently and have seen new life in this game. I will give it my recommendation and hope they continue down the path of customer satisfaction they have for too long strayed from.So give it a whirl. What have you got to lose other than your free time?

												While I do recommend AoC, I wouldn't suggest it for a long-time commitment.A game launched ahead of its time (which is not a good thing because it kind of needed a better engine), with incredibly fun questing due to the background lore, unique combat mechanics combined with fun PvE and PvP battles and one of those games that were worth calling a potential "WoW killer" at the time. It had everything that somebody could ask for even now; beautiful graphics, graphical violence, detailed lore based on the Conan universe, fun combat, voice-freaking-acting and a lot of promise right off the start. That is untill you get to leave the tutorial area....It's still a great amount of fun and worth throwing a little bit of money at it to get some extra areas and quests. But that's it really. The end-game is generic raids and that's about it. Some areas are locked to subscribers only, which are the end-end-game areas that you will have to go if you want to progress even further. Thankfully they improved their payment model, but it still is bad. There is some PvP to be had, but unless you are in the most populated server AND in one of the active and big guilds, you won't get much out of it.It fell short due to it being rushed as all hell, which is painfully obvious. You get to be introduced to mechanics at the tutorial area that are NEVER used again in the game like a single-player mode for story quests and a nice hub city to link everything together. After that you are thrown ALL OVER the map in a fairly generic area system. No quests apart from a few that can be easilly counted with maybe just 1 hand and the story quests are voice-acted afterwards. You get to have to do group quests which requires pure luck of finding somebody at your level to do them with and due to you not having them done you will fall short later on (depending on your class, some are simply too OP on everything) and have to tediously go through annoyingly hard quests.Also as I mentioned, some classes/builds are simply overpowered. Doing insane amounts of damage without long cooldown abilities and/or having too much survivability. It's one of the reasons that unless you are purely into the PvE part of the game and join a PvE server, you won't have too much fun unless you pick the objectively good builds.In conclusion, it's still a great game due to the lore and the environments and Funcom 101 stuff that they have nailed in both their MMOs and I could even argue that you are missing out if you don't give at least the tutorial area a try. As a "Conan" game it also does what it does very well and you will love the world you are in. However, it has many issues including the payment model itself so playing to rush to the end-game is not adviseable.

Age of Conan: Unchained, though old, is the only one that caught my attention. With fully voiced missions with cutscenes and an amazing loyalty to Conan's mortal world (whose original Robert Roward stories are special to me), and the details in the open world maps are incredible. 												As an avid fan of the Conan Franchise, from the Arnold Schwartzenegger Movies, to the original Novels and even some of the Comic Adaptations over the years, I was actually surprised to learn a Conan based MMO even existed, how did a 7 year old game fall under my radar?! It was a great idea with a large scale universe that is easy to immerse oneself in and explore for themselves. And it was Free to Play on Steam!? Of course I would try this out, I heard some less than favorable things about it but I figured I'd try it for myself. But was I satisfied with this game? No. Why? Well first off the combat system, now I know the game is old and that it wanted to try something new in regards to the typical MMORPG style of Combat; but seriously, it is tough to pull off, from what I can tell; many of the special attacks outside of one's main three left-right-upward thrust attacks, are executions one has to pull off by pressing the key to activate it again AFTER pressing it the first time (WHY!?) and then pressing the basic combat thrusts to fully execute the executions. I like the idea but the fact that the tutorial on how to do it is easily forgettable and very easy to mess up makes your attempt to pull off these executions pretty much a failure and no extra damage out of them will happen. That would not be so much of a problem if this games idea of difficulty scaling wasn't basically making every enemy you face off against when doing a side-quest literally 3 levels higher than you by the time you do it. The last time I played this game (and trust me, it will be the LAST time); it was when I was doing the lowest level possible side-quest for my character which was level 8 by the time I was doing it, and the quest involved me just having to kill 3 pirates; easy right? Not really; because they were level 11, and you CAN'T fight them one at a time, eventually they'll all join in and tackle me and kill me. I cannot even complete the lowest level side-quest in the game at Level 8; it's like the moment you reach level 6-8; the difficulty spikes up to levels that could reach Jupiter! Maybe if I can buy some good items from the shopkeeps; maybe that'll help me? Nope; not even high enough level for me to even buy them. And enemy grinding doesn't work because the cap for XP gains dies out at 2 levels or lower! The only time I have EVER seen ANYONE in game (which is rarity because the games' servers are empty), they have paid for the exclusive weapons via-microtransactions. That means the only way possible to beat the game after level 6 at minimum is to pay for good items with REAL MONEY. Now look; I know Free to Play and Microtransactions go hand in hand and you're probably saying; "What did you expect!? How else are they going to make money!?" And to be fair, I am not against Microtransactions; I think they are a necessary evil for games like these, however; I do NOT believe they should be forced upon the players to the point where it is only possible to continue with such (might as well put a paywall), nor do I think the exclusive items should be so overpowered that they create an imbalance between players who pay and players who don't. That said, why is it that a game that is so beautiful and enriched by the Conan Universe so lackluster!? I can only guess that my feelings are the same as others. I don't recommend this game for anyone, the game itself is not strong enough to stand on it's own and only got my attraction because of the Conan name. Conan deserves better.

Age of Conan: UnchainedVersion 5.1Playtime ~6 hoursSize ~25GBIn Age of Conan you play a barbarian or a wizard of your picking, you start off as a slave(totally not a Morrowind ripoff) on a ship that crashes and then ghosts whisper sweet nothings to you as you are washed on the shore where a friendly local old man tells you to head for Tortilla in order to gain freedom.As you move through jungle, slaying pirates, natives and gorillas alike, you finally reach gates of Tortilla. There the guard tells you that your shackle fashion is not okay in the city and you are forced to conform to the local acceptable dressing code instead.After that you're free to do nothing as there is a severe lack of low level quests, which changes at around level 9-10 where you get far too many quests, even though they're all the same under the hood. You spend most of the game at the local inn getting wasted and talking to the local cat.Leveling is slow and there is no one around to help you since the game seems to be on its last legs as there is barely anyone else to be found. Your days are spent creeping around static NPCs whose only purpose in life is to do barely anything.Sometimes you use a boat to teleport to another location full of natives and crocodiles but nothing much changes. You slay them or they slay you sometimes, repeat repeat. Combat was fun until I realized that essentially you get 3 of the same basic attack and to use a special attack you have to press two buttons in a sequence instead of one like in most games. All this does is reduce your keyboard lifespan. It does not add to the gameplay much besides having to remember which direction an ability needs.Playing alone is really tough since world NPCs respawn really fast and when you're done with one group, it will start respawning, locking you into an infinite wave survival.  This game could work a lot better if you dealt a bit more damage and enemies did not respawn as fast. I wanted to invite my son to play with me but the game mechanics were a bit too complex for a 9 year old. Though it is for the best since I would not want to damage his mind with how poor the game plays.I played until level 15 and could not do any more as it felt more tedious than a manual labor job. All you do is run from one bland place to another doing bland quests killing mostly bland enemies. There is no strategy, just monotone grind. Maybe it gets better in higher levels but if after 6 hours it is all the same, that is more than enough to say no. I originally intended to play until when you leave Tortilla but I changed my mind after all the mind numbing experience.======- Additional DownloadsAfter runnig the game from Steam, the launcher has to download more content. This puts up false expectations of being able to play as it is done downloading. Sorta like when gifting your nephew a Wii U but then having it to update for 3 hours straight.- Separate account registrationThe game does not use steamworks and forces you to register a separate account with their system. That's more nonsense to go through before you can jump into the world of Conan the Barbosa.- Slow launcher launchEvery time you open the game, launcher needs to rescan everything which takes longer than it should. Every. SINGLE. TIME.- Bad latencyI don't know which server I was assigned to, but the game would constantly average at 140ms which is ridiculous considering there's total of three other people playing. Though this is most likely due to them being unable to afford more servers since no one is playing.- Quest limit of 30You cannot have more than 30 active quests at a time. If you want new quests, you need to delete old ones. I get that this is an old game, but come on, update it once in a while to allow more than that.- Quest tracking limitYou can only have 3 quests being tracked at one time and you cannot have 0 tracked quests as at least one needs to be tracked at all time. The UI to track/untrack quests is also painfully clunky.  - One character slot limitSeriously!? Can't even try out other classes unless you either delete your existing character or create 10 new accounts. I suppose you need more registered accounts to show some activity to your bosses.- No populationIt feels like a ghost town. During all of my playthrough I saw 5 other players, one of whom invited me to a Russian clan where admin proceeded to purge all inactive accounts, dropping clan member count from 80-something to 7 including me.- Generic questsTypical mmo quests of going here killing X of that. Very monotone and it gets annoying to walk back and forth.+ Fun clothing and armorArmor, weapons and clothes are rather enjoyable to look at with the realistic barbarian style. It is always fun to just take an ax that does not have any glowing elvish inscriptions and smack some pirates with it.+ ExecutionsNot many MMOs have fancy executions. This is not one of them, but the executions Conan does have are fairly decent. Sometimes they go all wonky and animations don't exactly match but hacking someone's head off or taunting your target while your ax is embedded in their chest is rather fun as far as this sort of stuff goes.+ Low level enemies don't attackEnemies with much lower level than you will stop being hostile and will allow you safe passage. Saves some time when you have to go to same place a hundred times for all the different quests that unlock one after another rather all at once.ConclusionIt is a dying game standing on its last legs. Wish it went open source so that others could turn it into an actually epic adventure rather than having this mess of a tryhard mmo.Final rating 3/9Not worth the weight

												Age of Conan.  I’m not entirely sure where to start with this review.  I started playing the game in October 2015, after a friend told me that it was their go-to MMO, so I thought I would try it out.  For the age of the game itself, the graphics are not too shabby at all, and would happily put a few more modern MMOs to shame.  The downside to this comes when it’s World Boss time, and there are spells being cast, and exotic damage graphics galore, which really leech memory and induces spectacular lag.The play-style I found clunky at first, with the need to use key combos to make attacks work, but I got used to that.  Not being able to use a mount to get around the game until level 40 was a bug-bear, especially with the sheer amount of running around maps that’s required.  The map interface is pretty poor if you want to see where you are in relation to the rest of the world as there is no button that takes you directly back to viewing the area you’re in – you need to know the name of the area you’re in and select it from a drop-down list.  Local travel merchants in-game: location names not always accurate, so if you’re new and don’t know where you’re going, it can get expensive.Like most other MMOs I’ve played, Age of Conan has an in-game “item store”, where you can buy un-lockable chests, better mounts, un-lockable areas, etc..  Funcom (which will further be referred to as F.U.com) recently “re-vamped” this, in presumably and effort to make it more snazzy.  In my humble opinion, they failed miserably.  It is now open by default when you log-in to any toon, and it pops up at random intervals, usually when you’re in the middle of fighting something vaguely important.  The prices for the items within it also seemed to change – somewhat unsurprisingly they made everything more expensive, so you get less bang for your buck.Another of their latest “re-vamps” to the game is a daily login “reward” system.  This entails having yet another pop-up window in your face when you log into your toon, but not just the first time you log in each day, it’s there every time regardless of whether you’ve claimed your daily “reward” or not.  The “rewards” themselves are okay.  On top of this, if you’re a subscriber you also have the loyalty reward system, which is claimable from the item store, once per toon, but require you to have been subbed for different amounts of days depending on the reward being offered.  These don’t change month-to-month, and are only claimable as long are you are a subscriber.The latest update included a number things, one of the most notable being opening up pay-to-play/purchasable areas to free-to-play players who’ve already purchased the areas, but not raising the in-game currency cap for free-to-play players.  In terms of PvP, I have no experience of this in-game, and I'm not likely to venture into it either. Offline levels have disappeared in the lastest update too.  These were one of the perks that subscirbers could enjoy, where every few days you gained a level token you could use on a toon to level it up.While the game's fun to play overall, I won't recommend it.

Age of ConanFirst let me say I play a lot of MMORPGs and am subscribed to three of the largest and play others.  Age of Conan was a game I was excited for when it was released in 2008, as were many of my friends I played other MMOs with.  It was a hopeful challenger to the older and "Gold Standard" of MMOs, World of Warcraft or WoW.  It appeared to be a hit for the first couple of months by the sales and the community, patient as they were for the promised game, hung in for a few more months. Hawever, by the 5th month the game qucikly died off, like several other MMOs that didn't meet expectations of the consumers, leaving only the hopeful fans.  TL;DRThe game in general is lack luster by todays standards.  For a game still trying to get money out of your wallet via micro transactions and subscriptions, Funcom has done little to the graphics engine, combat system, and UI to make it  feel current, fluid, and fun. Play this if you are a fan of the Conan lore and old school RPGs and can adapt to the awkward combat system. FaultsThe chief complaints were that the game was buggy and the zones following the starting area felt unfinished and lacked end game content.  Although Funcom has fixed many of these issues over time, the game struggled to produce revenue with a small community.  As a result it was repackaged as a FTP in 2011 (Unchained edition) with a business model that limited your ability to play this game as an MMO if you do not purchase the expansions/subscription packages. This also had problems, much like Rift faces today, with step prices for content and pay-to-win/ pay-to-progress debates. Current Business ModelFuncom has recently removed some, not all, of the pay restrictions for non-subscribers to access content such as zones and instances.  You can purchase game packages including expansions, T1 & T2 gear sets, mounts, loot boxes, consumables, and bonuses via micro transactions. A set of Tier armor will cost you $60 USD while mounts range between $10-20 and expansions will cost just under $20 each.  Subscribers still pay $15 a month and recieve increased XP, loot, and currencies. GameplayAge of Conan offers a unique love/hate combat system.  The combat system is designed so that you can attack and block in multiple dirrections with combos.  However, the system feels unnecessarily complex, slow, and clunky with animations that lack a wow factor.  The combat performs more of what you would expect from a small indie team rather than a triple-A studio supporting a giant MMORPG. And compared to a MMORPG like Black Desert Online (BDO), the combat system is aweful. You can chose to play in two game settings, PvP and PvE, on three server types, PvE, PvP, and RP.  Player vs Player is enabled when you want to play in the sunlight with other players. On a PvE server, enemy NPCs are in the world to attack rather than actual players. Player vs Enviroment is the night phase and you will not encounter other players as well as have completely different quest lines. This is a open world game however some areas are instanced and the world lacks the size of WoW, ESO, Rift, and BDO.  GraphicsAge of Conan was a beautiful game when it was released and pushed the boundries of MMOs of the time period. However, by today's standards it is lack luster at best. The game lacks brilliant attack/spell animations leaving you with a feeling of blah when fighting with your character. Some people may not mind this but when combined with the slow awkward feel of the attacks, it is not very satisfying.  While other MMOs have updated the engine, combat, and textures to ncrease the graphical fidelity of the game world to current standards, Funcom has done very little to Conan. Compared to other triple-A MMOs you can play for free like WoW, SWTOR, ESO, Rift, and BDO, Age of Conan is a jewel in the rough and only shines in the story.StoryThe story is set in a great lore based world and this would be the only reason to recommend this game to anyone. The writing is great and interacting with the quests NPCs can be very enjoyable. I found myself laughing several times at the dialog. The voice acting isn't bad, but I wouldn't call it great either. You will encounter a wide range of accents which can aid with immersion and also break it when the large white viking looking barbarian suddenly speaks to you with an East Indian accent.  However, this is by far some of the best dialog I have experienced with NPCs in an MMO. RecommendationIf you are a fan of the Conan lore and enjoy RPGs, then this may be a game for you provided you can adapt to the awkward combat system.  If not, then there are several other FTP MMORPGs that offer a more enjoyable experience.
